title: Are all neutron stars also pulsars? If not why? - Quora

response.answer_text: A neutron star is the result of a huge star collapsing. So, imagine a star as large as Earth’s orbit, suddenly being compacted down to the size of a large city - from millions of miles across, to 30. Like an iceskater pulling in her arms during a spin, the star’s rotation speed increases as it shrinks - from perhaps 1 rotation every 30 days, to dozens or hundreds per second. Neutron stars have intense magnetic fields (in fact, some are called ‘magnetars’ when they first collapse because of the intense field…) the poles of the star’s magnetic field may not lie on the rotational poles of the star - and, that field accelerates ions and creates a sweeping beam of radiation as it spins. Then, like a light house, the beam of radiation can sweep past the Earth - and, we detect it as a very regular, fast pulse of electromagnetic energy. The first pulsar was found by Jocelyn Bell Burnell, who was analyzing radio telescope data; she named it “LGM-1” for Little Green Man, because it was thought that such a regular pulse at exact timing could only be from an artificial source. But - as it turns out - it’s a former star, about 30 miles across, spinning *very* rapidly… Not all neutron stars appear as pulsars; if Earth isn’t in the sweeping radio burst range, then we wouldn’t hear the rapid beeping of pulses. If the neutron star’s pole were pointed at or near the Earth, the magnetic fields creating the pulses wouldn’t push that energy toward us.

Beware, all pulsars are neutron stars BUT all neutron stars are not pulsars! We refer only those neutron stars as pulsars whose electromagnetic beam points towards the Earth. Pulsars are neutron stars emitting electromagnetic radiation along their magnetic poles, which manifest themselves as periodic pulses observed by us using ground based observatories or satellites. There may be many such neutron stars whose electromagnetic beam does not point towards the Earth at all!  Another, possibility is that some of them may emit very weak electromagnetic signal and still point towards the Earth but cannot be detected as their signal is much weaker than our current instruments can detect!

All Pulsars are Neutron stars, but not all Neutron stars are Pulsars. Here’s why: Pulsars are rapidly rotating neutron stars that produce electromagnetic radiation in beams that emanate from their magnetic poles. As the neutron stars rotate, If these beams are pointed towards Earth, they seem to ‘pulse’ – as seen from Earth - and hence the name. So it depends on which way the energy beams are pointing.

I'm assuming that what I've been told is true: We can only detect pulsars if their beams of electromagnetic radiation is directed towards Earth.That pulsars are the same as neutron stars, only that they emit beams of EM radiation out of their magnetic poles. So, isn't it possible that neutron stars emit EM radiation in the same fashion as pulsars, just not in the right direction for us to detect it?
